description: From Middle English gasen; akin to Swedish dialectal gasa and Gothic 𐌿𐍃𐌲𐌰𐍃𐌾𐌰𐌽 (usgasjan, “to terrify”).

entries.meaning: A fixed look; a look of eagerness, wonder, or admiration; a continued look of attention.
(psychoanalysis) In Lacanian psychoanalysis, the relationship of the subject with the desire to look and awareness that one can be viewed.
examples: She counters the tendency to focus on critical strategies of resisting the male gaze, raising the issue of the female spectator.

verbs.description: gaze (third-person singular simple present gazes, present participle gazing, simple past and past participle gazed)

examples: They gazed at the stars for hours.
